_**The Good Doctor**_ is an American [medical drama](/wiki/Medical_drama
"Medical drama") television series based on the 2013 award-winning [South
Korean series of the same name](/wiki/Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\) "Good Doctor
\(TV series\)"). [Daniel Dae Kim](/wiki/Daniel_Dae_Kim "Daniel Dae Kim"), the
actor, first noticed the series and bought the rights for his production
company. He began adapting the series and eventually shopped it to CBS, his
home network in 2015. CBS decided against creating a pilot. Because Kim felt
so strongly about the series, he bought back the rights from CBS. Eventually,
[Sony Pictures Television](/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Television "Sony Pictures
Television") and Kim worked out a deal and brought on [David
Shore](/wiki/David_Shore "David Shore"), creator of the Fox hit medical drama,
_[House](/wiki/House_\(TV_series\) "House \(TV series\)")_ , to develop the
series.[1]

The show is produced by [Sony Pictures
Television](/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Television "Sony Pictures Television") and
[ABC Studios](/wiki/ABC_Studios "ABC Studios"), in association with production
companies Shore Z Productions, [3AD](/wiki/3AD "3AD"), and Entermedia. David
Shore serves as [showrunner](/wiki/Showrunner "Showrunner") and Daniel Dae Kim
is an executive producer for the show.

The series stars [Freddie Highmore](/wiki/Freddie_Highmore "Freddie Highmore")
as Shaun Murphy, a young [savant](/wiki/Savant_syndrome "Savant syndrome")
[autistic](/wiki/Autism "Autism") surgical resident at San Jose St.
Bonaventure Hospital. [Antonia Thomas](/wiki/Antonia_Thomas "Antonia Thomas"),
[Nicholas Gonzalez](/wiki/Nicholas_Gonzalez "Nicholas Gonzalez"), [Beau
Garrett](/wiki/Beau_Garrett "Beau Garrett"), [Hill Harper](/wiki/Hill_Harper
"Hill Harper"), [Richard Schiff](/wiki/Richard_Schiff "Richard Schiff"), and
[Tamlyn Tomita](/wiki/Tamlyn_Tomita "Tamlyn Tomita") also star in the show.
The series received a [put pilot](/wiki/Put_pilot "Put pilot") commitment at
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")
after a previous attempted series did not move forward at [CBS Television
Studios](/wiki/CBS_Television_Studios "CBS Television Studios") in 2015; _The
Good Doctor_ was ordered to series in May 2017. On October 3, 2017, ABC picked
up the series for a full season of 18 episodes. The series is primarily filmed
in [Vancouver, British Columbia](/wiki/Vancouver,_British_Columbia "Vancouver,
British Columbia"). In March 2018, ABC renewed the series for a second season.

The series debuted on September 25, 2017. _The Good Doctor_ has received mixed
to positive reviews from critics, with particular praise given to Highmore's
performance, and strong television ratings.

##
Premise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Premise")]

The series follows Shaun Murphy, a young surgeon with [autism](/wiki/Autism
"Autism") and [savant syndrome](/wiki/Savant_syndrome "Savant syndrome") from
the mid-size city of [Casper, Wyoming](/wiki/Casper,_Wyoming "Casper,
Wyoming"), where he had a troubled childhood. He relocates to [San Jose,
California](/wiki/San_Jose,_California "San Jose, California"), to work at the
prestigious San Jose St. Bonaventure Hospital.[2]

## Cast and
characters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast and characters")]

###
Main[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Main")]

  * [Freddie Highmore](/wiki/Freddie_Highmore "Freddie Highmore") as Dr. Shaun Murphy, a surgical resident with autism and savant syndrome.[3] His savant abilities include near-photographic recall and the ability to note minute details and changes. He is portrayed in flashbacks to his teen years by [Graham Verchere](/wiki/Graham_Verchere "Graham Verchere").[4]
  * [Nicholas Gonzalez](/wiki/Nicholas_Gonzalez "Nicholas Gonzalez") as Dr. Neil Melendez: [Attending](/wiki/Attending_physician "Attending physician") [Cardiothoracic](/wiki/Cardiothoracic "Cardiothoracic") surgeon in charge of surgical residents.[3] He is also engaged to Jessica Preston until episode 12.
  * [Antonia Thomas](/wiki/Antonia_Thomas "Antonia Thomas") as Dr. Claire Browne, a surgical resident who forms a special connection with Shaun.[5]
  * Chuku Modu as Dr. Jared Kalu, a surgical resident from a wealthy family.[6]
  * [Beau Garrett](/wiki/Beau_Garrett "Beau Garrett") as Jessica Preston: The hospital in-house attorney and Vice President of Risk Management. She is the granddaughter of the hospital founder and a friend of Dr. Glassman.[7]
  * [Hill Harper](/wiki/Hill_Harper "Hill Harper") as Dr. Marcus Andrews, Chief of Surgery, [attending](/wiki/Attending_physician "Attending physician") [plastic surgeon](/wiki/Plastic_Surgery "Plastic Surgery"), and board member.[8]
  * [Richard Schiff](/wiki/Richard_Schiff "Richard Schiff") as Dr. Aaron Glassman, President of the San Jose St. Bonaventure Hospital and [attending](/wiki/Attending_physician "Attending physician") [neurosurgeon](/wiki/Neurosurgery "Neurosurgery"), who has been a mentor and good friend of Shaun since he was 14.[9][10]
  * [Tamlyn Tomita](/wiki/Tamlyn_Tomita "Tamlyn Tomita") as Allegra Aoki, Chairman of the San Jose St. Bonaventure Hospital Board and Vice President of the foundation that controls the hospital's funding.[11]

###
Recurring[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Recurring")]

  * Dylan Kingwell as Steve Murphy: Shaun's younger brother (in flashbacks).[4] He also portrays Evan Gallico, a boy in the present that resembles Shaun's brother and is suffering from stage 4 [osteosarcoma](/wiki/Osteosarcoma "Osteosarcoma").
  * [Graham Verchere](/wiki/Graham_Verchere "Graham Verchere") as a young Shaun Murphy in flashbacks.
  * Paige Spara as Lea: Shaun's love interest/ former neighbor.
  * [Christina Chang](/wiki/Christina_Chang "Christina Chang") as Dr. Audrey Lim
  * [Chris D'Elia](/wiki/Chris_D%27Elia "Chris D'Elia") as Kenny, Shaun's new neighbor, who moves into Lea's apartment.
  * [Fiona Gubelmann](/wiki/Fiona_Gubelmann "Fiona Gubelmann") as Dr. Morgan Reznick, a new resident (joins the cast for five episodes with the possibility of becoming a regular in season 2).[12] As a resident, Morgan will turn out to be a rival for Claire. (debuted in "She").[13]
  * [Will Yun Lee](/wiki/Will_Yun_Lee "Will Yun Lee") as Dr. Alex Park, an ex-cop who decided to become a doctor (debuted in "Heartfelt").[14]

### Notable
guests[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Notable guests")]

  * Irene Keng as Dr. Elle McLean, a surgical resident (only appears in the pilot, however had series regular status for said episode) [8][15]
  * [Jasika Nicole](/wiki/Jasika_Nicole "Jasika Nicole") as Carly[16]
  * [Eve Gordon](/wiki/Eve_Gordon "Eve Gordon") as Nurse Fryday[16]
  * [Eric Winter](/wiki/Eric_Winter "Eric Winter") as Matt Coyle, a suave doctor who charms the hospital's staff, until he makes explicit advances towards one of them.[17]
  * [Marsha Thomason](/wiki/Marsha_Thomason "Marsha Thomason") as Dr. Isabel Barnes, Marcus' wife. [18]

##
Episodes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Episodes")]

No. | Title | Directed by | Written by | Original air date | U.S. viewers  
(millions)  
---|---|---|---|---|---  
1 | "Burnt Food" | [Seth Gordon](/wiki/Seth_Gordon "Seth Gordon") | [David Shore](/wiki/David_Shore "David Shore") | September 25, 2017 (2017-09-25) | 11.22[19]  
On the way to begin his surgical residency at San Jose St. Bonaventure
Hospital, Dr. Shaun Murphy witnesses an airport sign fall and shatter glass
onto a young boy. With his unique ability to visualize the internal body and
using improvised methods and tools, Shaun is able to stabilize the boy. In a
hospital board meeting, Dr. Aaron Glassman, president of the hospital, tries
to convince the board to hire Shaun, despite his autism. Flashbacks give us a
picture of Shaun's childhood and his motivation for becoming a doctor.  
2 | "Mount Rushmore" | [Mike Listo](/wiki/Mike_Listo "Mike Listo") | David Shore | October 2, 2017 (2017-10-02) | 10.93[20]  
Dr. Neil Melendez is doing rounds with Dr. Claire Browne and Dr. Jared Kalu.
Melendez calls out Shaun for arriving late on his first full day. A middle
aged woman is brought into the ER with abdominal pain. Shaun immediately
diagnoses a malignant tumor. As punishment for lateness, Shaun is assigned
'scut work', where his attention to detail gets him in trouble. After
rechecking a discharged young girl's test results, Shaun races to her home,
annoying her parents over the late hour, but eventually saving the girl's
life.  
3 | "Oliver" | [John Dahl](/wiki/John_Dahl "John Dahl") | William Rotko | October 9, 2017 (2017-10-09) | 10.69[21]  
Shaun and Claire fly to San Francisco Municipal Hospital to get a liver for a
transplant patient. After learning the helicopter can't take off due to bad
weather, they resort to a police escort. Meanwhile, at the Hospital, Chuck,
the recipient of the liver, is discovered to have alcohol in his system, a
development that could void his transplant eligibility. Chuck later confesses
he had one drink at his daughter's graduation. In order to protect its
reputation and ability to supply transplants to future patients, the hospital
denies Chuck the liver. Shaun and Claire arrive back, having kept the liver
viable, only to learn that it is to be taken to a patient at another hospital.  
4 | "Pipes" | [Steven DePaul](/wiki/Steven_DePaul "Steven DePaul") | Thomas L. Moran | October 16, 2017 (2017-10-16) | 10.60[22]  
Barb Allen, 22 weeks pregnant, and her husband arrive at St. Bonaventure,
hoping the doctors can save their baby. A large non-cancerous tumor is growing
on the fetus and must be removed in order to save his life. Despite the
serious risks both to her and the baby, Barb insists on surgery. Meanwhile,
Shaun and Claire are assigned a patient, Olivia, who has a boil in her genital
area. However, when doctors attempt to drain it, a fibroid tumor is found to
be wrapped around a nerve. The surgery to remove it will cut off all feeling
in Olivia's genitals. Shaun comes up with a solution that allows her to keep
feeling in her genital area.  
5 | "Point Three Percent" | [Larry Teng](/wiki/Larry_Teng "Larry Teng") | [David Hoselton](/wiki/David_Hoselton "David Hoselton") | October 23, 2017 (2017-10-23) | 10.39[23]  
Shaun notices a young boy, Evan, who has an uncanny resemblance to his
deceased brother Steve. Evan was brought to the hospital by his parents for a
possible fracture to his arm. However, we discover that he is actually
suffering from bone cancer, a fact his parents have kept hidden from him.
Meanwhile, the other members of the team try to diagnose an older man, brought
in by his estranged son, with a severe allergy condition causing him to
convulse violently. Claire and Jared determine that the man is suffering from
a cystic form of tapeworms located in his skull. A successful surgery is
performed by Dr. Glassman.  
6 | "Not Fake" | [Michael Patrick Jann](/wiki/Michael_Patrick_Jann "Michael Patrick Jann") | Simran Baidwan | October 30, 2017 (2017-10-30) | 10.60[24]  
Shaun and the rest of the residents are working the graveyard shift when
numerous casualties from a wedding bus crash come in. Among the victims are a
woman with severe, visible burns, on whom Jared tries an experimental
procedure, and a young man with a severely damaged leg. Tensions arise between
the patients parents and fiancée over the best choice for treatment; his
parents want to amputate the leg, his fiancée is in favour of an experimental
bone-replacement procedure. After treating a patient, Claire realises that a
woman has been left behind at the crash site.  
7 | "22 Steps" | [David Straiton](/wiki/David_Straiton "David Straiton") | Johanna Lee | November 13, 2017 (2017-11-13) | 10.14[25]  
Shaun encounters Liam, an autistic patient brought in to the hospital. Having
to face prejudice from the young man's parents, Dr. Melendez defends him for
the first time and acknowledges his exceptional abilities. On Dr. Glassman's
directive, Claire continues with therapy sessions in order to curb her guilt
over inadvertently causing the death of a patient. Jared deals with a 73-year-
old man with severe chest pains thus needing urgent medical attention and a
pacemaker; but the patient states his desire is to die.  
8 | "Apple" | [Nestor Carbonell](/wiki/Nestor_Carbonell "Nestor Carbonell") | David Renaud | November 20, 2017 (2017-11-20) | 9.97[26]  
While shopping at a grocery mart for apples, a robbery takes place. With
Shaun's communication limitations, he puts the lives of two customers on a
first date at risk, leading to a young woman getting shot. Shaun's neighbor
Lea hugs him after he admits that he made a mistake with someone getting hurt.
During surgery, Dr. Lim questions Claire's ability to not let her emotions get
the better of her because of a racist patient. This leads to an argument
between the two with Dr. Lim ordering Claire to leave the operating room.
Claire puts her emotions in check to save the life of the racist patient much
to the satisfaction and delight of Dr. Lim.  
9 | "Intangibles" | [Bronwen Hughes](/wiki/Bronwen_Hughes "Bronwen Hughes") | Karen Struck | November 27, 2017 (2017-11-27) | 9.25[27]  
The team takes on the case of a young boy from the Congo who has severe
congenital heart anomalies; Murphy's latest encounter with his neighbor Lea
has him confused. He takes flirting lessons from Claire and notes and charts
what he sees in regards to the "flirting trifecta". Meanwhile, Claire along
with a lab tech search for a misplaced tissue sample from a woman with
possible throat cancer.  
10 | "Sacrifice" | Michael Patrick Jann | Lloyd Gilyard Jr. | December 4, 2017 (2017-12-04) | 9.03[28]  
Shaun has reluctantly agreed to Dr. Glassman's repeated suggestions to meet
with a therapist, but ultimately changes his mind after a new patient, Bobby
Otto, convinces Shaun to stop letting people tell him what to do. Claire runs
into an uncomfortable situation with Dr. Matt Coyle, who makes unwanted sexual
advances toward her during a patient consultation. Jared finds out and
physically threatens him. As a result, Jared is fired. After a tense dinner
with Jessica, her father and Dr. Melendez, Jessica states that she doesn't
want to have children.  
11 | "Islands Part One" | [Bill D'Elia](/wiki/Bill_D%27Elia "Bill D'Elia") | Thomas L. Moran & William Rotko | January 8, 2018 (2018-01-08) | 8.30[29]  
Shaun and Lea embark on an impromptu road trip. Shaun drives, drinks Tequila,
sings karaoke, all for the first time, and experiences his first kiss with
Lea. Melendez and Andrews operate on [conjoined twins](/wiki/Conjoined_twins
"Conjoined twins"), one of whom needs a kidney. Complications develop and the
operation to separate them, planned for six months after the kidney surgery,
must be done immediately. The operation goes well until it's discovered the
twins have not awakened from the surgery. Melendez decides it's more important
to be with Jessica and that he can be a "father" in other ways.  
12 | "Islands Part Two" | [Cherie Nowlan](/wiki/Cherie_Nowlan "Cherie Nowlan") | Thomas L. Moran & William Rotko | January 15, 2018 (2018-01-15) | 9.33[30]  
Shaun returns to the hospital after his trip and gives Dr. Glassman his two
weeks’ notice, intending on moving to Hershey to be with Lea. The twins suffer
complications from their surgery; Katie is not getting enough blood flow to
the brain, while Jenny’s heart is failing. Despite the doctors’ best efforts
to save both twins, Jenny dies on the operating table. Jessica is forced to
look into previous misconduct at the hospital in which white doctors were only
warned instead of fired, after allegations of racism by Kalu’s lawyer; as a
result, Jared is reinstated. Jessica tells Melendez that she wants to break up
because she feels like she is standing in his way of being a father.  
13 | "Seven Reasons" | Mike Listo | David Shore & David Hoselton | January 22, 2018 (2018-01-22) | 9.61[31]  
While treating a Muslim patient, Shaun senses she is lying and makes
controversial claims about how she sustained her injuries. Melendez punctures
the [bronchus](/wiki/Bronchus "Bronchus") of the patient during surgery and is
put under investigation after Shaun questions if his personal life is
affecting his work. While Claire assists in a surgery on a stroke patient who
had an [aneurysm](/wiki/Aneurysm "Aneurysm") with Dr. Lim, she learns that
Coyle got a new job and a raise. They inform the patient's wife that he needs
surgery or he will die, but she refuses to conset until Claire explains the
reality of the situation. Shaun asks Glassman to be friends, but Glassman
decides to give him his own space and not be friends, which upsets Shaun.  
14 | "She" | Seth Gordon | Simran Baidwan | February 5, 2018 (2018-02-05) | 9.63[32]  
The four residents including the new Dr. Morgan Reznick are paired off in
competition; Reznick and Browne with Melendez, Murphy and Kalu with Lim.
Murphy and Kalu are faced with a [gender dysphoric](/wiki/Gender_dysphoria
"Gender dysphoria") patient, Quinn, which leads to friction when Murphy claims
people can only be their biological gender. Murphy and Kalu determine that
Quinn has [testicular cancer](/wiki/Testicular_cancer "Testicular cancer")
along with fragile bones caused by puberty blockers. Browne and Reznick tend
to a male patient that has contracted a superbug resistant to all medication,
as a result of taking leftover persciption medication for the wrong purpose.
Drs. Andrews and Barnes see a fertility specialist as they are having trouble
concieving.  
15 | "Heartfelt" | [Regina King](/wiki/Regina_King "Regina King") | Thomas L. Moran & Johanna Lee | February 26, 2018 (2018-02-26) | 7.82[33]  
A female teen goes through a risky surgery to implant a sternum so she can
live a normal life without being confined to her house. A young male teen
initially rejects the idea of having a convicted killer's liver transplanted
in him, but without it he has a day to live. A former 15 year veteran cop
turned doctor, Alex Park, is skeptical of the convict, Boris's, motives.
Allegra talks to Dr. Andrews about a young wealthy donor, Aidan Coulter, but
Andrews says being involved with him might give people the wrong idea and that
she used sex to solicit donations. At a fundraiser, Jared tells Claire he
loved her and thought maybe she would one day love him, but came to the
realization that isn't true leaving the status of their relationship unknown.  
16 | "Pain" | [Allison Liddi-Brown](/wiki/Allison_Liddi-Brown "Allison Liddi-Brown") | William L. Rotko & David Renaud | March 12, 2018 (2018-03-12) | 9.88[34]  
Shaun, Claire, and Alex assist Melendez with one of his first patients, a man
named Hunter who was paralyzed in a motorcycle accident ten years prior.
Jared, Morgan, and Andrews attend a patient who has an infection caused by
plastic surgery. Claire's estranged mother shows up at the hospital in an
attempt to reconnect. Andrews sees an infertility specialist that tells him
there is a surgery that could help him with his sperm count, but that there is
a risk of impotence. Alex does a background check on Kenny which sheds light
on his criminal past leading him to suggest Shaun is being used by him.  
17 | "Smile" | Bill D'Elia | David Hoselton & Karen Struck | March 19, 2018 (2018-03-19) | 9.03[35]  
Shaun and Alex treat teenaged Gretchen's [Mobius
Syndrome](/wiki/Mobius_Syndrome "Mobius Syndrome"), enabling her to smile;
Andrews persuades an insurance executive to cover the surgery. Morgan and
Claire's patient, "Lucy Callard," is actually an [identity
thief](/wiki/Identity_theft "Identity theft") who let her insurance lapse to
pay her son's college tuition and failed to fill her post-operative antibiotic
prescription due to fear of discovery. Morgan convinces the real Lucy Callard,
a [painkiller](/wiki/Analgesic "Analgesic") addict, to enter rehab; Claire
gains the trust of the imposter, Beatrice, who dies of an infection. Jared
romantically pursues his burn-victim patient, Celez, after she completes her
treatment; he is also offered a job in Denver. Kenny takes advantage of Shaun.
Shaun urges Glassman to date hospital barista Debbie; they hit it off over
their interest in [classic cars](/wiki/Classic_car "Classic car"), but
Glassman suddenly experiences [aphasia](/wiki/Aphasia "Aphasia") at the end of
their dinner date.  
18 | "More" | Mike Listo | David Shore & Lloyd Gilyard, Jr. | March 26, 2018 (2018-03-26) | 9.52[36]  
Glassman tells Shaun that he has an inoperable [glioma](/wiki/Glioma "Glioma")
and eighteen months to live. Glassman accepts his death, but agrees to
additional imaging for Shaun's sake; this yields a worse
[prognosis](/wiki/Prognosis "Prognosis") of four months to live. Glassman
takes Shaun to a park his late daughter loved so they can enjoy the time
Glassman has left. Shaun determines how a [minimally
invasive](/wiki/Minimally_invasive_procedures "Minimally invasive procedures")
[biopsy](/wiki/Biopsy "Biopsy") could be performed; Glassman is diagnosed with
an operable form of cancer; he will pursue treatment. Collegiate patient Caden
suffers a complication after treatment for a [fraternity](/wiki/Fraternity
"Fraternity") [hazing](/wiki/Hazing "Hazing") injury. Jared and Alex question
Caden's friend, but Jared is put off by Alex's distrustful nature. Shaun
determines that he [erred](/wiki/Medical_error "Medical error") in clamping
Caden's artery. He proposes a risky procedure to save Caden's life and offers
to take full responsibility for performing it, but Melendez decides they will
perform it together. Caden survives and Melendez invites the team out for
drinks, which Morgan finds perverse; Melendez hopes a doctor supports her when
she inevitably kills a patient. Shaun decides he must admit his mistake to
Andrews, even though Glassman staked his position on Shaun's success; Glassman
leaves the decision up to Shaun, and accompanies him to meet with Andrews.

Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Development")]

In May 2014, [CBS Television Studios](/wiki/CBS_Television_Studios "CBS
Television Studios") began development on an American [remake](/wiki/Remake
"Remake") of the hit South Korean [medical drama](/wiki/Medical_drama "Medical
drama") _[Good Doctor](/wiki/Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\) "Good Doctor \(TV
series\)")_ with Daniel Dae Kim as producer. Kim explained the appeal of
adapting the series as "something that can fit into a recognizable world, with
a breadth of characters that can be explored in the long run".[37] The story
of a pediatric surgeon with autism was to be set in [Boston](/wiki/Boston
"Boston") and projected to air in August 2015.[38][39] However, CBS did not
pick up the project and it moved to [Sony Pictures
Television](/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Television "Sony Pictures Television"), with a
[put pilot](/wiki/Put_pilot "Put pilot") commitment from
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company") in
October 2016. The series is developed by [David Shore](/wiki/David_Shore
"David Shore"), who is executive producing alongside Kim, Sebastian Lee, and
David Kim.[40] ABC officially ordered the series to pilot in January 2017.[41]

On May 11, 2017, ABC ordered the show to series as a co-production with Sony
Pictures Television and [ABC Studios](/wiki/ABC_Studios "ABC Studios"),[42]
and it was officially picked up for a full season of 18 episodes on October 3,
2017.[43] On March 7, 2018, ABC renewed the series for a second season.[44] It
will premiere in the fall of 2018

###
Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Casting")]

On February 17, 2017, [Antonia Thomas](/wiki/Antonia_Thomas "Antonia Thomas")
was cast as Dr. Claire Browne, a strong-willed and talented doctor who forms a
special connection with Shaun.[5] A week later, [Freddie
Highmore](/wiki/Freddie_Highmore "Freddie Highmore") was cast in the lead role
as Dr. Shaun Murphy, a young surgeon with autism; and [Nicholas
Gonzalez](/wiki/Nicholas_Gonzalez "Nicholas Gonzalez") was cast as Dr. Neil
Melendez, the boss of the surgical residents at the hospital.[3] The next
month, Chuku Modu was cast as resident Dr. Jared Kalu (originally Dr. Jared
Unger);[6] [Hill Harper](/wiki/Hill_Harper "Hill Harper") as head of surgery
Dr. Marcus Andrews (originally Dr. Horace Andrews); Irene Keng as resident Dr.
Elle McLean;[8] and [Richard Schiff](/wiki/Richard_Schiff "Richard Schiff")
was cast as Dr. Aaron Glassman (originally Dr. Ira Glassman), the hospital
president and Shaun's mentor.[9][42] Schiff was shortly followed by [Beau
Garrett](/wiki/Beau_Garrett "Beau Garrett") as hospital board member Jessica
Preston and a friend of Dr. Glassman.[7] In September 2017, [Tamlyn
Tomita](/wiki/Tamlyn_Tomita "Tamlyn Tomita") was promoted to the principal
cast as Allegra Aoki.[11]

In April 2018, it was revealed that [Will Yun Lee](/wiki/Will_Yun_Lee "Will
Yun Lee"), [Fiona Gubelmann](/wiki/Fiona_Gubelmann "Fiona Gubelmann"),
[Christina Chang](/wiki/Christina_Chang "Christina Chang"), and Paige Spara
had been promoted to series regulars for the second season, after recurring in
the first as Alex, Morgan, Audrey, and Lea, respectively.[45] In addition, it
was announced that Chuku Modu would not return for the second season.[45]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Surrey_City_Hall_%2830491047242%29.jpg/220px-
Surrey_City_Hall_%2830491047242%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Surrey_City_Hall_\(30491047242\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Surrey_City_Hall_\(30491047242\).jpg "Enlarge")

The [Surrey, British Columbia](/wiki/Surrey,_British_Columbia "Surrey, British
Columbia") city hall serves as the fictional San Jose St. Bonaventure Hospital
in exterior shots.[46]

###
Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Filming")]

Production on the pilot took place from March 21 to April 6, 2017 in
[Vancouver](/wiki/Vancouver "Vancouver"), [British
Columbia](/wiki/British_Columbia "British Columbia").[47][48] Filming for the
rest of the season began on July 26, 2017, and concluded on March 1, 2018.[49]

###
Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Music")]

[Dan Romer](/wiki/Dan_Romer "Dan Romer") serves as the primary composer for
the series.[50]

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Release")]

###
Broadcast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Broadcast")]

_The Good Doctor_ began airing on September 25, 2017, on ABC in the United
States,[51] and on [CTV](/wiki/CTV_Television_Network "CTV Television
Network") in Canada.[52] [Sky Living](/wiki/Sky_Living "Sky Living") acquired
the broadcast rights for the United Kingdom and Ireland.[53] [Seven
Network](/wiki/Seven_Network "Seven Network") airs the series in
Australia.[54] [Wowow](/wiki/Wowow "Wowow"), the largest Japanese private
satellite and pay-per-view television network in Japan acquired the rights to
broadcast the series beginning in April 2018.[55] In the Netherlands, the
series began airing on January 29, 2018, on [RTL 4](/wiki/RTL_4 "RTL 4") and
on video-on-demand service [Videoland](/wiki/Videoland_\(Netherlands\)
"Videoland \(Netherlands\)").[56]

###
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Marketing")]

A full-length trailer was released for ABC's May 2017 [Upfront
presentation](/wiki/Upfront_\(advertising\) "Upfront \(advertising\)"), which
[/Film](/wiki//Film "/Film")'s Ethan Anderton described the concept as feeling
like "_[House](/wiki/House_\(TV_series\) "House \(TV series\)")_ meets _[Rain
Man](/wiki/Rain_Man "Rain Man")_ , that just might be enough to make it
interesting". However, he questioned "how long can audiences be entranced by
both the brilliance of [Highmore's] character's savant skills and the
difficulties that come from his autism in the workplace."[57] Daniel Fienberg
of _[The Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood
Reporter")_ felt the trailer was "both kinda progressive and really dated". He
added, "Too much felt on-the-nose—especially Hill Harper as the main
character's detractor and Richard Schiff as his noble defender", while also
commentating that "On-the-nose/premise is how you have to trailer a show like
this, and maybe spaced out over 43 minutes it won't grate."[58] Ben Travers
and Steve Greene for [IndieWire](/wiki/IndieWire "IndieWire") called it "a
serious trailer for a serious subject. The first glimpse of Highmore's
character hints that they're toeing the line between presenting a thoughtful
depiction of his condition and using his perceptive abilities as a kind of
secret weapon."[59] The trailer had been viewed over 25.4 million times after
a week of its release, including over 22 million views on
[Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook").[60]

The pilot was screened at ABC's [PaleyFest](/wiki/Paley_Center_for_Media
"Paley Center for Media") event on September 9, 2017.[61] On March 22, 2018,
members of the cast as well as executive producers Shore and Kim attended the
35th annual PaleyFest LA to promote the series, along with a screening of the
season finale of the first season.[62]

The series premiere earned a 2.2/9 rating in the 18- to 49-year-old
demographic, with 11.22 million total viewers, making it the most watched
Monday drama debut on ABC in 21 years, since _[Dangerous
Minds](/wiki/Dangerous_Minds_\(TV_series\) "Dangerous Minds \(TV series\)")_
in September 1996, and the highest rated Monday drama in the 18–49 demographic
in 8.5 years, since _[Castle](/wiki/Castle_\(TV_series\) "Castle \(TV
series\)")_ in March 2009.[81] Factoring live plus seven-day ratings, the
pilot was watched by a total of 19.2 million viewers and set a record for DVR
viewers with 7.9 million, surpassing the record of 7.67 million set by the
[pilot](/wiki/Pilot_\(Designated_Survivor\) "Pilot \(Designated Survivor\)")
of _[Designated Survivor](/wiki/Designated_Survivor_\(TV_series\) "Designated
Survivor \(TV series\)")_ in 2016.[82] According to _[TV Guide](/wiki/TV_Guide
"TV Guide")_ 's November 13-26 issue, the October 9 episode attracted 18.2
million viewers, beating out both _[NCIS](/wiki/NCIS_\(TV_series\) "NCIS \(TV
series\)")_ and _[The Big Bang Theory](/wiki/The_Big_Bang_Theory "The Big Bang
Theory")_ for the most viewed primetime show that week.[83]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Good_Doctor_\(TV_series\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Critical response")]

The [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") website
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reported a 58%
approval rating with an average rating of 5.49/10 based on 38 reviews. The
website's consensus reads, "_The Good Doctor_ 's heavy-handed bedside manner
undermines a solid lead performance, but under all the emotionally
manipulative gimmickry, there's still plenty of room to improve."[84]
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), which uses a weighted average,
assigned a score of 53 out of 100 based on 15 critics, indicating "mixed or
average reviews".[85]

Giving his first impression of the series' pilot for [TVLine](/wiki/TVLine
"TVLine"), Matt Webb Mitovich stated, "_The Good Doctor_ boasts great DNA...
[and] has the potential to be a refreshingly thought-provoking hospital drama,
based on the buttons pushed in the pilot alone." He enjoyed the "warm dynamic"
of Schiff and Highmore, while describing Thomas' character as "our emotional
'in' to Shaun's distinct, distant world". He noted that "it takes a while to
build up momentum", but concluded that "the very final scene packs quite a
punch, as Dr. Murphy unwittingly puts a colleague on notice".[86]

_[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_
television critic, [James Poniewozik](/wiki/James_Poniewozik "James
Poniewozik"), notes in his Critic's Notebook column, that for the most part
the drama is a "hospital melodrama with whiz-bang medical science, a dash of
intra-staff romance and shameless sentimentality." Discussing the main
characters of Dr. Aaron Glassman (Richard Schiff) and Dr. Shaun Murphy
(Freddie Highmore), however, Poniewozik writes that "Mr. Schiff is convincing
in the role and Mr. Highmore is striking in his." [87]

Speaking of Freddie Highmore's [Golden Globe](/wiki/Golden_Globe_Award "Golden
Globe Award") nomination on Monday, December 11, 2017, for his role in _The
Good Doctor_ , Laura Bradley, writing for _[Vanity
Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_\(magazine\) "Vanity Fair \(magazine\)")_ says: "...
Freddie Highmore received the awards recognition that has long and unjustly
eluded him..." Bradley feels that Highmore's performance has been "the central
key" to the show's enormous success and while the show had lukewarm reviews,
most critics have praised Highmore's work. [88]
